there's a lot of them one point that i would make in here that i think some people overlook is

next slide please back to the flow picture that we had i'm
showing a different view of it here i call this typical but as
anybody that's built chips will know there is no such thing as a typical flow what we show in moving
between these various phases is a set of arrows on the bottom that are the linear flow where you
design an architecture you code up the rtl you synthesize it it creates gates
you move into a layout phase and then ultimately you take the chip out it goes to fab get through test and
debug test automation you sell it make a lot of money everything is wonderful the problem is that the real world
doesn't work this way and what you see on the top are a number of back arrows that show
you moving from a phase that you were at to a previous stage and as the arrows are showing you can
actually move all the way from layout back to architecture it's rare and if you've done your job right
you shouldn't have to do this but keep in mind that that backwards flow is a part of this entire process it's
also critical to note by the way that when you're moving through this flow the most important thing that i can suggest
that you do is tape out early and often and what i mean by that silly expression
is not that you actually tape out your chip multiple times but that you get through the entire
process as early in the design flow as you possibly can and the reason for this is the whole
concept of unknown unknowns you don't know what you don't know until you get all the way to the tape out
phase similarly frankly when the chips come back what you need to be very careful about is if something doesn't work the
way that you expect it to keep in mind that if it's a digital chip for example
you may have mistakenly thought that everything in that chip was digital but if you had a phase locked loop in it
if you had a certies if you had something else there's an analog block at work there and if something's going wrong
make sure that you go back and test the assumptions that were built into it that suggest
that you can box that in in a particular way next slide please

critical point to keep in mind is that checklists are a means to an end they're not the end
i've worked in companies where people end up getting overwhelmed with checklists and they
get to the point where they simply follow the checklist and believe that by following the checklist
they're doing the right thing the checklist is there as think of it as a guard rail it's not there to tell you what to do

intended to show you that you're managing risk one of the companies that i was

what i mean and what they meant by risk is that you take what you're building
break it down by a lot of the subtasks and identify whether those subtasks are unique and
the difficulty level associated with them and part of what you get from that is a non-linear score
and manage your company by trying to drive down that overall risk what this does is it
forces you to focus on areas that are difficult and it makes you focus on them early

yes so um when we started silicon catalyst roughly five years a little bit over
five years ago it was a time when investment in
semiconductors was actually fairly low in particular venture capitalists were
very reluctant to invest in chip companies because there was a feeling that chips
were becoming more and more of a commodity number one and number two there were alternatives investments
which were much less risky this is epitomized perhaps by apps which
which could be built in a very short period of time you could get to a demonstrate or a first viable product
in a matter of months while as we just learned from what mark showed you right it takes a few years to actually build a
chip and so we decided well obviously innovation is necessary
in semiconductors we need semiconductor solutions we need chips and and so what can we do
to remedy that situation one of the first things we did is we went out and we interviewed a lot of startups
and semiconductor companies and asked them what are your issues so if you just look at the issues they
look all pretty much equivalent right there's none that stand out dramatically if you look a little bit
closer right you see that um as a matter of fact eda and lab tools which are of course necessary
to design chips and and the prototype builds are a little bit um more weighted
than all the other issues that you go there but once you go to expenses and challenges actually the picture becomes
much clearer if you look at expenses right one of the key things is of course
raising money the second thing is managing your time of course the longer it takes to design a chip the
more likely you are to um to run out of money and if you look at the challenges right then
very clearly eda tools and their silicon prototyping are the things
that dominated and so we went and thought what what can we do to to help with this
and next slide please and the answer is actually pretty obvious right if we can provide
the tools which are pretty expensive a typical tool set to design a chip a
state-of-the-art tool set depending on um depending on exactly what you get right can cost several million dollars
and so if we could provide the tools for free the intellectual property chips these
days are built not only by designing from scratch but the large majority of the areas typically occupied
by things like memory cores and arm core and maybe a risk five core
ios that you don't build again you you reuse them and if we could
also provide for free um not only the tools and the ip but also a
path to fabrication a spot on a multi-project wafer
then a company would need to raise much less cash next please
than if they had to fund all this if if you if you had to fund all this eda ip the testing of the chip and the
fabrication of the chip you're going to spend most of the capital that you raise
not on just the team but also in acquiring all of these if however an incubator could provide
all this as an in-kind contribution then you need much less cash
the rest you raise as in kind and the cash that you spend as is illustrated there in red
goes towards actually hiring the people and developing the product and not so much into essentially spending on things that
that are collateral that are absolutely necessary but that don't really contribute to
making your startup more or less successful anybody can buy these things so what we did next please in silicon
catalyst was um we went to the industry
and next we went to the industry right and we recruited
income partners now this is a result after five years we started with very few but if you see we have different
categories of in-kind partners that provide their tools or services or goods
for free or for a very steep discount to a company that wants to design a chip to
our portfolio companies right and examples among them that are really important rda companies you see synopsis
there you see mentor there ansys silvaco so you can get their tools for free
for up to two years which is a good period to get started perhaps a good
period to actually get into a prototype in terms of ip we provide um the two
most prevalent cores here arm and risk five in the form of sci-fi we also have
synopsis r courses and all their other iop which is great if you go to services we have a
